body:
Error is from here:

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/2023836c2f97dd6fe417e0b6f2295efdd3346fb8/onnxruntime/core/providers/cpu/tensor/scatter_nd.cc#L72-L76

ONNX spec says 

> indices is an integer tensor. Let k denote indices.shape[-1], the last dimension in the shape of indices. indices is treated as a (q-1)-dimensional tensor of k-tuples, where each k-tuple is a partial-index into data. Hence, k can be a value at most the rank of data.

Input rank is 1 (1D tensor with 10 elements).
Indices_shape is {0, 2} meaning k is 2. 

As input rank is 1, you can't have a tuple of 2 values providing a location in the input data as it only has one dimension. Based on that the code looks to be correct.

Side note: the indices are actually empty as the first dim is 0 and we could probably exit prior to the shape validation. but that seems orthogonal as the indicies input would still be invalid if the first dim value was > 0.

> Error is from here:
> 
> https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/2023836c2f97dd6fe417e0b6f2295efdd3346fb8/onnxruntime/core/providers/cpu/tensor/scatter_nd.cc#L72-L76
> 
> ONNX spec says
> 
> > indices is an integer tensor. Let k denote indices.shape[-1], the last dimension in the shape of indices. indices is treated as a (q-1)-dimensional tensor of k-tuples, where each k-tuple is a partial-index into data. Hence, k can be a value at most the rank of data.
> 
> Input rank is 1 (1D tensor with 10 elements). Indices_shape is {0, 2} meaning k is 2.
> 
> As input rank is 1, you can't have a tuple of 2 values providing a location in the input data as it only has one dimension. Based on that the code looks to be correct.
> 
> Side note: the indices are actually empty as the first dim is 0 and we could probably exit prior to the shape validation. but that seems orthogonal as the indicies input would still be invalid if the first dim value was > 0.

Got it, thanks.
